reviewText: This DVD documents a concert recorded in January 2006 in the Prague Estates Theater in memory of Mozart's visits to Prague and of his 250th birthday, and the setting could not be more festive. The venue, however, obviously presented some problems filmically as well as sonically. The director and the camera team should have known that both distant shots and dizzyingly rotating aerial shots are totally inappropriate for concert footage, and should have focused on the interaction of the orchestra musicians instead of stepping away from the musical proceedings. Filming the conductor from floor level is plain ugly. The audio is neither very detailed nor transparent, rather blended so that woodwinds, brass and timpani don't cut through the string fabric. In fact, the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra can be heard to better effect in much older recordings with Neumann, Belohlávek and other great conductors. In addition, most of the film appears to be slightly grainy and not up to today's standards. Musically, I find the production also somewhat disappointing. The overture to Don Giovanni blazes away nicely, but without much inspiration or character. Fittingly played on a basset clarinet by the impressive Sharon Kam, the Clarinet Concerto K. 622 still is fairly lightweight Mozart, and the present performance does not bring out any depths perhaps hidden in the score. In the Prague Symphony K. 504, both the conductor and the orchestra are on their toes, but Manfred Honeck offers little new insight into the music. All in all, these are good routine performances flawed by a mediocre production.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is an enjoyable concert consisting of three popular works of maturity and which have all been associated with Mozart in Prague. The concerto was first played in Prague as was the opera, Don Giovanni and also The 38th symphony known as the Prague. The connection goes further in so far as all these early performances were held in the venue used for this recording, the Estates Theatre. So, in effect, this recording is a gala celebration of Mozart first performances in the Estates Theatre.The concert opens with a crisp and dramatic rendering of the Don Giovanni Overture with its concert ending. In the actual opera, of course, the overture does not have a finite ending as it leads straight into the opera itself.The soloist in the following clarinet concerto plays the basset clarinet which provides the lower range of notes envisioned by Mozart and not available on the more usual modern clarinet. Again this is given a crisp performance with none of the lingering that some may remember from the earlier performances by the like of Jack Brymer for example.The concert ends with an equally brisk and crisp performance of the symphony with the emphasis upon drama rather than sensitivity. This is not meant to be a criticism, rather an observation of general approach.All the works are played in style, with energy and tight control of rhythm. The orchestra is scaled down although still larger than that probably envisioned by Mozart and certainly with greater power as modern instruments are used to full dramatic effect. This is an energetic approach to all these works and will not be to all tastes. It would be possible to imagine an alternative approach with greater emphasis upon textural matters and with more individual instrumental nuance. All of these considerations would be easier to deliver with an authentic style of orchestra or a modern chamber orchestra with fewer players for example.The hall is considered to be very beautiful but when the lighting is turned down for the performances the hall becomes very dark so the stage has to be brightly spotlit. This produces a very contrasty effect on all long shots and clearly limits the opportunities for visual presentation. The shape of the hall, being long and narrow and of considerable proportional height would not help the camera operators either. Nevertheless it has little effect on the majority of the camera work which is focussed much closer and often on individual players or small groups which are very clearly captured. The sound on this disc is excellent and is as forthright as are the performances. It is presented in DD 5.1, DTS 5.1 and stereo formats.Overall this disc is enjoyable in its own way and can be recommended if the program also appeals. I personally would hope to find a rather less forceful account of these works or ones with more authenticity in terms of texture and nuance of phrasing as my main reference. Good examples of this can easily be found on numerous CDs these days. In general terms therefore I would suggest that this is more of a 4 star offering rather than a definitive achievement but nevertheless still capable of giving pleasure without too much heartache.
summary: Enjoyably forthright  performances which largely overcome difficult lighting conditions
Title: N/A

reviewText: ... and which loved him. Prague.The concert consists of three pieces written and premiered in Prague and takes place in the actual theater where Don Giovanni was premiered, a gorgeous green and gilt four-tier box. (I recently read an interview with Sherrill Milnes, who sang the Don in that very theater, and he commented that it practically gave him heart failure to climb the spiral staircase to the dressing rooms knowing that they had not been changed since Mozart's day and that Mozart must have climbed those very stairs.) The Don Giovanni Overture is given a dramatic yet crisp performance by the slimmed down Czech Philharmonic under Manfred Honeck, a Viennese maestro about to begin his tenure as the music director of the Stuttgart Opera. Then comes one of the greatest concertos for any instrument, the magnificent Clarinet Concerto in A, K. 622. Sharon Kam, a rising star of the clarinet, an Israeli whom I first heard a year or so ago on a DVD with the Israel Philharmonic. I recall making a note to follow her career. And here she is, playing not the usual A clarinet but a basset clarinet which is after all the instrument that Mozart actually wrote this concerto for. It has three additional bass notes down to the C below middle C and Mozart used them in the piece; those playing the standard A clarinet have to play some of those notes an octave up. I've become used to the basset clarinet version and much prefer it. Kam, an attractive young woman, is a marvelous musician as well as having technique to spare. Her playing is supple and fluid but not wanting for fireworks when needed. She is matched by the unusually nuanced playing of the Czech Philharmonic (which, I note, has no female players in its pared-down 35-member form).The 'Prague' Symphony, No. 38 in D, K. 504 -- also premiered in this theater only a few months after Don Giovanni -- is one of my favorite Mozart symphonies and I'm very particular about how it is done. It must, as it does here, have drama and grace in equal measure. It is in three movements, having no minuet, and it is in Don Giovanni's dominant key - D major - with many thematic similarities without, as far as I know, any direct quotations. The Czech Philharmonic play as to the manner born. One can see on their faces that they love this music. The subtle gradations of dynamic and tempi feel natural and perfectly right for the music. I love this performance.The DVD is only 66 minutes long but I found that it was enough. I will admit, though, that after it finished I then went back and listened to several passages again (the concerto's Adagio, the whole of the Giovanni overture, the Andante of the symphony), reveling in their beauty. This one's a keeper.Scott Morrison
summary: A Gala on Mozart's Actual 250th Birthday in a City He Loved ...
Title: N/A

reviewText: This performance was recorded on 27 January 2006, Mozart's 250th birthday, as part of the 24hours Mozart broadcast. The DVD is billed as a Mozart Gala from Prague. Filmed in the gorgeous Estates Theatre: its walls and seats covered in green damask and gold filigree, it is a petite theatre featuring a classic 18th Century shoebox configuration and a ceiling that reaches towards the heavens. Its sound is stunning in its purity. Before the science of Acoustics was born, theatre designers had already reached perfection. Mozart loved this theatre and this city ("They understand me here", he wrote of Prague) and he reciprocated by composing many of his greatest late masterpieces to be premiered in this very theatre.The overture to Don Giovanni K.527 fittingly begins this disc. Don Giovanni premiered in here on 29 October 1787, conducted by Mozart himself. It was an immediate sensation, providing Mozart with a feeling of satisfaction that eluded him in Vienna. Next comes Mozart's seminal Concerto for Clarinet and Orchestra in A major K.622. Representing a new depth of thinking and expression for the concerto genre: with its intimate musical dialog, its melancholy lyrical elegance and emotional profundity, the Clarinet Concerto, though the first of its kind, remains the paradigm of this medium. Sharon Kam plays the Basset Clarinet; an instrument developed by Mozart's close friend, the superb clarinettist Anton Stadler and Stadler's brother, Johann. The basset clarinet has a range extending a minor third below the normal clarinet. Stadler played the basset clarinet for the premier of the concerto on 16 October 1791, a mere 7 weeks before the composer's death. Today, it is usually played in a version for the clarinet in A, with the lowest notes transposed up an octave. The original score was lost so Kam plays a reconstruction. She extracts an astonishing warmth of tone and a wealth of supple effects of register from the instrument. It is an eye-opening performance for those of us used to the traditional A clarinet version. Ms. Kam is splendid, as are the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra under Manfred Honeck. They exhibit a lovely, understated purity of orchestral sound and a simple lyrical expressiveness: as authentic a Mozart performance style as is possible given the provenance of these works. It is a marvelous performance.The disc ends with the Symphony No.38 in D major K.504 "Prague". It, too, was first performed in this theatre on 19 January 1787, during Mozart's first trip to the city. It was a great success. Although it is unclear for what occasion it was originally composed (it may have been meant for Mozart's 'bottom drawer' to be utilized for one of his concert tours). It is unusual for lacking a 3rd movement minuet. Nevertheless, it is inextricably linked with the city whose name it bears. This is a splendid performance. I hated to see this superb DVD end.This DVD has a picture format of NTSC shot wide screen in 16:9 anamorphic. The picture is crystal clear. Sound formats are PCM stereo, Dolby Digital 5.1 and DTS 5.1 Digital Surround. All are splendid with both Dolby and DTS providing great spatial depth and a fine rear ambiance. The region code is 0 worldwide. The disc runs 66 minutes.Wonderful Mozart from Prague makes this DVD highly desirable. Strongly recommended.Mike Birman
summary: Mozart played beautifully on his 250th birthday
Title: N/A

reviewText: Another wonderful DVD from Euroarts!This recording  is of the gala concert to commemorate Mozart's 250th birthday (and not surprisingly it is an all Mozart affair),  beginning with the  Overture to Don Giovanni, followed by the Concerto for Clarinet and Orchestra (featuring  Sharon Kam, playing the basset clarinet) and closing with the Symphony No. 38 "Prague".The concert  was recorded at the Estates Theatre in Prague on Jan 27th, 2006.  This is a small, horseshoe shaped theater that has a series of 5 stacked loge boxes surrounding and rising above the main audience floor; to say the decor is opulent would be a gross understatement. The concert is played by the Czech Philharmonic under the skillful baton of Manfred Honeck. Interestingly enough, all three pieces performed at this concert had their first performances at this very same venue in the late 1780's and early 1790's.The city of Prague was very special to Mozart as it was here that his music seemed to be most appreciated by the nobility and the public in general; here he received accolades the he could only dream of in Vienna. Thus it is not surprising that Mozart chose to honor Prague with these first performances; the city and its inhabitants were obviously very special to him.Highlight of the disc:While the Overture and the "Prague" symphony were expertly played with pace, feeling and enthusiasm, it was, Sharon Kam, the  soloist for the clarinet concerto, who provided the highlight of this DVD. Kam is a clarinetist extraordinaire, and she uses a basset clarinet (instead of the usual clarinet in A) for this performance. This is the same type of instrument that was used in the original performance in 1791; it has  a slightly lower  range than the clarinet in A and Kam is able to use her instrument to perfection,  giving the bass notes  a rich,  velvety tone. Simply magnificent to watch as well as hear.The disc is recorded beautifully; featuring great camera angles and superb audio. It was  then professionally edited and transcribed to disc; this DVD is of the highest quality.Negatives?...well, yes one...the audience's response to this concert. What I discovered on this disc were three magnificently performed works (especially the solo by Sharon Kam) and yet the reception by those in attendance that night, might at best, be described as...subdued; a token of almost "ho-hum" appreciation. In other words...polite applause, just long enough to not be considered rude.  From my perspective (the DVD) I saw a performance that was simply stellar; well, I can still offer my own "bravos" and "bravas" from the comfort of my home.Simply a magnificent DVD; anyone who loves  Mozart, or just good classical music will want to have for their collection. 5 Stars...more if I could.
summary: A Mozart concert  from Prague...a treasure
Title: N/A

reviewText: I agree completely with the early favorable reviews of the Mozart Gala from Prague. First, unlike many galas that contain snippets of various compositions, this one features complete performances of three works associated with the city of Prague. Second, the concert was beautifully filmed and recorded in the historic Prague Estates Theater. Third, the Czech Philharmonic played beautifully. Finally, the clarinet concerto featuring Sharon Kam was outstanding.I was surprised when I read gpk's three star review, which describes the performance as routine,mediocre and disappointing. He is entitled to his opinion, but I could not disagree more. It is hard to imagine a more beautiful performance on the anniversary of Mozart's 250th birthday.
Title: N/A
